subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit automatically
msgSnippet: ...  ... So does Agitator only report invariants it uncovers, or does it also generate tabular data representing the output it received for each input?
messageBody:
albsavoia wrote:

> >How does a computer know what kinds of tests I need to write?
> >How does a computer know what the expected results are?
>
> Good questions J.B.
>

<snip />
> As you might guess, Agitator cannot know the expected results - only
> the developer can know that. What Agitator can do for you is
> generate test data that gets you code coverage and then shows you
> what it observed in the form of class and method invariants. These
> observations are in the form of Java boolean valued assertions. For
> example:
>
> File.canWrite() == true
>
> Or
> File.getPath().equals("C:\foo\bar")
>
> Or
> File.list().length == 14

So does Agitator only report invariants it uncovers, or does it also
generate tabular data representing the output it received for each input?

It sounds like Agitator does this:

* try a bunch of inputs
* notice patterns in the outputs/state of the code
* say to the programmer, "It looks like XYZ is invariant. Would this
be a useful assertion?"

My original response was "Great tool for testing legacy code, useless
for TDD," but this makes me think otherwise:

<snip />
> Combined with Agitator's ability to automatically generate very
> relevant test data and achieve very high code coverage automatically
> (through data flow analysis and other dynamic techniques), automated
> observations are a powerful and very efficient way to create unit
> tests quickly to get the developer to consider inputs and conditions
> that they might have missed. But the developer input is still
> required to decide if what Agitator observed is what the code is
> suppsed to do.

This looks like another method of receiving feedback on the quality of
the tests one chooses to write, even when doing TDD.

> I'll stop here because I don't want to use this forum to promote
> Agitator, but I wanted to clear any misconceptions and answer J.B.'s
> questions.

No, no, this is quite good. It sounds interesting, and is certainly
worth examining. It makes me wish I had a project to which to point it
and try it out.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
